indicators.justification:
In Portugal, there is the public platform PORBIOTA — Portuguese e-Infrastructure for Information and Research on Biodiversity — (1) which oversees the storing, organising and disseminating biodiversity and environmental data, thereby supporting research on biodiversity and ecosystems that connects academia public administration and civil society.

In a collaboration between PORBIOTA with academia, the Portuguese Node of GBIF launched the Portugal Biodiversity Data Portal (2). This portal is the main reference as far as biodiversity data is concerned, and provides access to information on biodiversity from the 10 national institutions that publish occurrence data through GBIF, and data published by foreign institutions for Portugal. 

The platform promotes and facilitates the publication of biodiversity data by other national institutions, who can publish hit, sample, or checklist data using the software data standards promoted by GBIF.

Other alternative platforms do exist (3) (4) but seem either niched or incomplete.

(1) Website of PORBIOTA https://www.porbiota.pt/
(2) Portugal Biodiversity Data Portal https://www.gbif.pt/
(3) Website of Naturdata https://naturdata.com/
(4) Website of Rural Dados http://www.ruraldados.pt/

indicators.justification:
Climate data in Portugal is overall poorly developed. 

What can be close to climate vulnerability information being provided as open data is accessible at Portal do Clima (1) based on a forecasting model RCP (2) for greenhouse gases developed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 2014.

In such a dynamic context as climate, using data from 2014 is rather outdated. Moreover, the model is missing all vulnerability data, as it only outputs temperature and precipitation, and is also missing data coverage in Portuguese islands of Madeira and Azores.

Data re-use is not encouraged as it is expect "ensuring compliance with copyrights and intellectual property rights when you reproduce, transmit, display, copy, distribute or use data retrieved" (3).

(1) Website "Portal do Clima" http://portaldoclima.pt/pt/
(2) Model of Representative Concentration Pathway https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representative_Concentration_Pathway
(3) Data re-use Disclaimer http://portaldoclima.pt/en/bottommenuen/disclaimer/

indicators.justification:
Company beneficial ownership information is available publicly at a Ministry of Justice website (1). It is only available through a query-based website, thus not available in machine-readable open data. Although the information seems to be updated daily, with no real missing information, the public website (promoted by the Ministry of Justice) appears rather outdated, showing several limitations of UX, not allowing any exploration of the data. Consequently, the information is not available as structured open data, nor as a dataset.

(1) Website "Publicação On-Line de Acto Societário e de outras entidades" https://publicacoes.mj.pt/Index.aspx

indicators.justification:
The data that relates to Cause of death, standardized to the International Classification of Causes of Death (ICD), is accessible in Portugal at SICO/eVM platform (1). 

eVM is a real-time electronic mortality surveillance system that automatically analyzes data extracted from the Death Certificate Information System (SICO) database.

SICO is the mortality information system in Portugal, based on the electronic registration of death certificates, made by doctors in the exercise of their profession, in accordance with the legal framework in force.

However, data is not available download or even accessible trough tabular data. Only presented visually. Also, data is missing gender data across the board.

There are a couple more sources of data related to death but these are either outdated or not standardized (2) (3).

(1) SICO/eVM platform https://evm.min-saude.pt/#shiny-tab-dashboard
(2) Open data Portal dados.gov https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/obitos-n-o-1/

indicators.justification:
Portuguese «Certidão Permanente» – made available by the Order 1513/2008 — is an online certificate, with the same content as the one in paper – all registry acts in force and the pending requests (1). This information is continuously updated, including all the new registries and the pending requests relating to that immovable property . Although it is a pdf format, it is not a frozen image of the registry, it is continuously updated, as the pdf file is generated each time you access the information using the code.

According to article 104 of the Land Registry Code (LRC), anyone can apply for certificates of registry information and archived documents, as well as oral or written information about its contents (2). It is a consequence of the public nature of the land registry. There is no need to prove a legitimate interest.

Sill, online information on Land registry is accessible online only to professional users through dedicated website.

(1) Portaria n.º 1513/2008
https://dre.pt/pesquisa/-/search/443950/details/maximized
(2) Código do Registo Predial https://dre.pt/web/guest/legislacao-consolidada/-/lc/34544675/view?q=Decreto-Lei+n%C2%BA%20224%2F84
(3) Website "Predial online" https://www.predialonline.pt/PredialOnline/

indicators.justification:
Providing government budget and spending information as open data has not been a priority for the Portuguese administration. Consequently, this information is either fragmented, or not accessible in machine readable format.
There is some very crude data available at the Portuguese Open Data Portal (1) which is dwarfed by the static PDF version of the national budget (2).
There is a promise by the government that government spending data/information will be openly accessible, but so far it has not yet be implemented.

indicators.justification:
With respect to the capability of municipalities to manage data, namely open data, the city of Lisboa has clearly lead the way. Lisboa first published its open data strategy in 2017, and began publishing its data through a municipal data portal Lisboa Aberta (1)(2).

indicators.justification:
Portugal has got a decent framework supported by different pieces of legislation with regards to  protection of personal data. Established as a constitutional right, protection of personal data is ruled by the following laws:
(1) Article 35 of the Portuguese Constitution
(2) Law 58/2019 which ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
(3) Law 59/2019 ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (UE) 2016/680 on the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data.
(4) Law n.º 41/2004 ensures the implementation at national level of Regulation (UE) 2002/58/EC on the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector

In 2021, Portugal enacted (5) Law n.º 27/2021 Portuguese Charter of Human Rights in the Digital Age which further supports protection of personal data in the country. However, this was not taken into account as they fall outside the formal evaluation period of this study , ending in May 1, 2021.

indicators.justification:
Portugal has been a late comer to collecting and publishing data on public finances. Still in recent years, concrete steps have been taken, such as joining the Open Government Partnership.

Law 151/2015 "Lei de Enquadramento Orçamental" (1) sets the regime of the budget process, the rules of execution, accounting and budget and financial reporting, as well as the rules of inspection, control and audit. In terms of publication of data, it is made compulsory for the government to make (aggregated) budget information public. It is put rather simply, with no reference to other requirements to the data.
Also, Law 26/2016 defines rules of access to public administration information (2), and in its Art. 2 it states the Principle of Open Governance, bringing core concepts of open access, but again not dwelling into anything technical or quality-related.

(1) Law 151/2015 https://www.dgo.gov.pt/legislacao/Documents/Lei_151-2015_LEO.pdf

indicators.justification:
In 2019, Lav 4/2019 was enacted, and it dictated the creation of a new entity ("Entidade para a Transparência") that would lead the state's effort to scrutinize the gains of public servants in the high roles, such as politicians. (1)

Then in a joint effort to further legalise lobbying, in January 2021, three different proposals that relate to lobbying were discussed and approved by the parliament (2). These were: 
1- Bill No. 30/XIV/1.ª which regulates the activity of Professional Representation of Interests (Lobbying)
2- Bill No. 181/XIV/1.ª which regulates lobbying activity and creates a Transparency Register and a Legislative Footprint Mechanism
3- Bill No. 253/XIV which approves transparency rules applicable to private entities that carry out legitimate representation of interests before public entities and proceeds to the creation of a transparency register of the representation of interests.
Although steps have been taken, in practice, the enforcement of this legislation relies upon the new entity "Entidade para a Transparência" that is now postponed to begin in 2023, reflecting the idea of a sluggish process overall (3).

(1) Law 4/2019 https://www.parlamento.pt/Legislacao/Documents/Legislacao_Anotada/EstatutoEntidadeTransparencia_Simples.pdf
(2) Article by Transparency International https://transparencia.pt/parecer-projetos-lei-lobbying/ 
(3) Article by newspaper Expresso https://expresso.pt/politica/2021-04-16-Nova-Entidade-para-a-Transparencia-so-em-2023-2555c72a

indicators.justification:
The matters of right to information (RTI) / freedom of information (FOI) relate closely with (2) Law 26/2016 which approves the regime for access to administrative and environmental information and for the reuse of administrative documents.

According to this law, the entity "Comissão de Acesso aos Documentos Administrativos (CADA)" is an independent administrative entity, which works with the Assembly of the Republic and aims to ensure compliance with the legal provisions relating to access to administrative information (1). 

Specifically with respect to data on the performance of right to information (RTI) / freedom of information (FOI) processes, CADA publishes an yearly report with relevant qualitative and quantitative information.
